title: A 1-year Randomised, Double-blind Placebo-controlled Study to Evaluate the Effects of Memantine on Rate of Brain Atrophy in Patients With Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: Pre-clinical studies have demonstrated that memantine can decrease the neuronal toxicity associated with excessive glutamate release and calcium overload in neurons. Previous studies have shown that memantine helps to treat the symptoms of Alzheimer's Disease (AD). In AD, the rate of brain tissue loss, or atrophy, is faster than in normal aging and this seems to go hand in hand with some of the symptoms of the disease. This suggests that memantine treatment in AD could provide both symptomatic improvement and neuro-protective effects. The purpose of this study was to show whether memantine, in addition to providing symptomatic benefits, can slow the rate of brain atrophy as assessed using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) technology.
description_detailed: The primary objective of this study was to evaluate the effects of memantine on the rate of brain atrophy compared to placebo in patients with AD (moderate severity) over a 1-year period. This was a multinational, randomised, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled, fixed-dose study (20 mg memantine). The study also included secondary imaging, cognitive and behavioural measures.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: After a 3-week run-in period during which MRI scans were performed, the patients were randomised to either placebo or memantine and stratified according to AChEI treatment. Memantine-treated patients started with 5 mg/day and were uptitrated by 5 mg/day every week for 4 weeks. The target dose of 20 mg/day was administered from the start of Week 4.
participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: The patients were recruited from each investigator's outpatient clinic.

measures.title: Controlled Oral Word Association Test (COWAT): Baseline Efficacy Scores
measures.description: COWAT: Verbal fluency test. The patient was asked to, during 1 minute, generate as many words as possible beginning with three pre-specified letters. The total score was calculated as the sum of acceptable words generated, with higher scores indicating lower cognitive impairment.

measures.title: Category Fluency Test (CFT): Baseline Efficacy Scores
measures.description: CFT: The patient was asked to, during 1 minute, say aloud as many different words as possible from the categories animals and fruits. The total score was calculated as the number of appropriate words generated, with higher scores indicating lower cognitive impairment.

measures.title: ADAS-cog-Orientation Test (ADAS-cog-OT): Baseline Efficacy Scores
measures.description: ADAS-cog-OT: A subscale of the ADAS-cog test with 8 questions and designed to determine how well oriented the patient is with regard to time and place. The total score was calculated as 8 minus the total number of correct answers, with higher scores indicating greater cognitive impairment.

measures.title: Stroop Interference Test - Incongruent (SIT-I): Baseline Efficacy Scores
measures.description: SIT-I: A test to demonstrate the reaction time. Names of colours are printed in a different ink than the colour named. The time taken to complete the test was recorded, as was the number of errors. The more time spent and the higher number of errors indicates lower reaction time.

measures.title: Stroop Interference Test - Congruent (SIT-C): Baseline Efficacy Scores
measures.description: SIT-C: A test to demonstrate the reaction time. Names of colours are printed in the same ink as the colours named. The time taken to complete the test was recorded, as was the number of errors. The more time spent and the higher number of errors indicates lower reaction time.

measures.title: Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE): Baseline Efficacy Scores
measures.description: MMSE: Brief, structured examination of mental status that assesses orientation, memory, attention, naming, comprehension, and praxis. The range is 0 to 30, with a lower score indicating a worse mental state.

measures.title: Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI): Baseline Efficacy Scores
measures.description: NPI: A scale specifically developed to assess behavioural disturbances in patients with dementia. It is based on responses from the caregiver. The range is 0 to 120, with higher score reflecting higher frequency and severity of the disturbances.

outcomeMeasures.title: Total Brain Atrophy Rate Estimated Using Brain Boundary Shift Integral (BBSI)
outcomeMeasures.description: Measures direct changes in total brain volume per visit interval (screening to Week 4, 42, or 52 or from Week 4 to Week 42 or 52)
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: FAS-MRI: Full-analysis set for all patients in the all-patients-treated set (APTS) who had at least one valid MRI scan \>=6 months after initiation of investigational medicinal product (IMP). The FAS (full analysis set, efficacy set) replaces the intention-to-treat (ITT) concept used in older terminology.

analyses.groupDescription: Linear mixed model relating direct change in brain volume (BBSI) to time and its interaction with treatment group. This model additionally includes a time-by-AChEI group interaction as a fixed effect.

outcomeMeasures.title: Changes in Total Hippocampal Volume (HCV)
outcomeMeasures.description: Estimated mean changes in total HCV

analyses.groupDescription: Mixed model repeated measurements (MMRM) with unstructured covariance including time, time-by-treatment, visit, pre-treatment HCV, and AChEI group.

outcomeMeasures.title: Cognitive and Behavioural Outcomes: Controlled Oral Word Association Test (COWAT) Total Score
outcomeMeasures.description: Adjusted mean change from baseline on cognitive and behavioural scores. COWAT: Verbal fluency test. The patient was asked to, during 1 minute, generate as many words as possible beginning with three pre-specified letters. The total score was calculated as the sum of acceptable words generated, with higher scores indicating lower cognitive impairment

analyses.pValueComment: The p-value represents the difference from placebo for COWAT at Week 52 (MMRM).

outcomeMeasures.title: Cognitive and Behavioural Outcomes: Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) Total Score
outcomeMeasures.description: Adjusted mean change from baseline on cognitive and behavioural scores. MMSE: Brief, structured examination of mental status that assesses orientation, memory, attention, naming, comprehension, and praxis. The range is 0 to 30, with a lower score indicating a worse mental state

analyses.pValueComment: The p-value represents the difference from placebo for MMSE at Week 52 (MMRM).

seriousEvents.organSystem: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)
Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certainAgreement.otherDetails: Publication of the results by the Investigator will be subject to mutual agreement between the Investigator and H. Lundbeck A/S. Manuscripts and abstracts must be sent to H. Lundbeck A/S at least one month prior to submission for publication or presentation.

explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests memantine, described as reducing neuronal toxicity from excessive glutamate and calcium influx and providing symptomatic benefits in AD. Memantine is a small-molecule, uncompetitive NMDA (glutamate) receptor antagonist that acts by modulating neurotransmission rather than directly targeting core AD protein pathology (amyloid or tau). citeturn0search1turn0search6

Act: Key extracted details from the trial description — intervention: memantine versus placebo in a 1-year randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study measuring rate of brain atrophy by MRI. The primary aim is to determine whether memantine provides symptomatic benefit and/or slows brain atrophy (neuroprotection), not to target amyloid or tau specifically. citeturn0search0turn0search8
Web search results supporting drug/intervention info: PubMed listing of the 1-year randomized memantine brain-atrophy trial (trial details and primary outcome). citeturn0search0

Web search results supporting mechanism and regulatory/therapeutic context: ALZFORUM summary describing memantine as a small-molecule, low-to-moderate affinity, uncompetitive NMDA receptor antagonist used in moderate–severe AD; DrugBank entry confirming modality = small molecule and NMDA antagonist. citeturn0search1turn0search6

Reflect: Classification justification — by the provided category definitions, memantine is not a biologic and does not directly target amyloid or tau pathology (so it is not a 'disease-targeted biologic' or a 'disease-targeted small molecule' under the narrow definition of targeting AD pathology). Its primary clinical use and mechanism are to modulate glutamatergic neurotransmission to improve symptoms and potentially offer neuroprotection; thus it fits 'cognitive enhancer' (improving cognitive symptomatology rather than directly targeting core AD pathology). The trial’s MRI outcome (atrophy rate) tests a neuroprotective hypothesis but does not change the mechanism classification. citeturn0search1turn0search0

Notes / ambiguity: The protocol mentions potential neuroprotective effects (slowing atrophy), which is a disease-modifying concept; however, memantine’s mechanism is best classified as symptomatic/neuroprotective via NMDA modulation rather than a small-molecule that directly targets amyloid or tau pathology. If a stricter interpretation of 'disease-targeted small molecule' were used (i.e., any small molecule intended to modify disease course), one could argue for that category — but per the supplied category definitions (which emphasize targeting core AD pathology), 'cognitive enhancer' is the most accurate. citeturn0search1turn0search0
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests memantine, a small‑molecule uncompetitive NMDA (glutamate) receptor antagonist that modulates glutamatergic neurotransmission (i.e., a neurotransmitter receptor target) rather than targeting core AD protein pathology such as amyloid or tau. citeturn0search2turn0search1

Act: Key extracted details — intervention: memantine (up to 20 mg/day) versus placebo in a 1‑year randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled study with MRI-measured brain atrophy as the primary outcome. The drug’s described mechanism is NMDA receptor antagonism and symptomatic/neuroprotective action via modulation of glutamate‑mediated excitotoxicity. Based on these intervention/mechanism details, assign D) Neurotransmitter Receptors. citeturn0search0turn0search2

Reflect: Confirmation — memantine’s primary pharmacologic action is on NMDA (a neurotransmitter receptor), so CADRO category D is the most specific fit. Although the trial measures brain atrophy (a disease‑modifying outcome) and explores neuroprotection, the mechanism of action is modulation of neurotransmission not direct targeting of amyloid, tau, ApoE/lipids, inflammation, etc.; therefore D) Neurotransmitter Receptors is appropriate. citeturn0search6turn0search1
- PubMed: 'Memantine and brain atrophy in Alzheimer\'s disease: a 1-year randomized controlled trial' (trial details and primary outcome). citeturn0search0
- ALZFORUM: summary of memantine pharmacology and clinical use (NMDA antagonist description). citeturn0search1
- DrugBank: memantine entry (modality = small molecule; mechanism = NMDA receptor antagonist). citeturn0search2turn0search3
- PMC review on Alzheimer pharmacologic treatments summarizing memantine as an uncompetitive NMDA receptor antagonist and its symptomatic/neuroprotective rationale. citeturn0search6
